thread.title: Turnball says Australians exempt from Trump’s ban
thread.title_full: Malcolm Turnball says Australians exempt from Trump’s ban | Daily Mail Online

author: Australian Associated Press
title: Turnball says Australians exempt from Trump’s ban
text:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has announced Australian passport holders are allowed to travel to the United States despite the visa ban.
Australia has been given assurances its dual nationals will be exempt from President Donald Trump 's controversial immigration ban.
On Tuesday, Mr Turnbull confirmed the development following a phone call from Australia's ambassador to the US in Washington Joe Hockey.
'Australian passport holders will be able to travel to the United States in the same way they were able to prior to the executive order,' Mr Turnbull told Sky News.
Scroll down for video
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has announced Australian passport holders can enter the US
The confirmation comes as Mr Turnbull has come under fire for not joining other world leaders in publicly condemning President Trump's executive order imposing a temporary ban on people from seven majority-Muslim countries.
'When I need to ... give frank advice, fearless advice to the United States government, I do so privately,' he said.
'To do my job, which is to advance Australia's interests, protect Australian citizens, ensure that Australians can travel to and from the United States in the normal way, to do that, it is best that I reserve my comments on American domestic policy for private discussions with the president or his senior officials.'
Opposition leader Bill Shorten used Facebook to take a swipe at Mr Turnbull.
Mr Turnbull confirmed on Tuesday Australian dual nationals will be allowed to travel to the US
While the US should be able to go about its business without interference from Australia, there were some issues where silence would be interpreted as agreement, he wrote.
'For that reason, I need to say Mr Trump's ban on refugees based upon their religion or country is appalling and ought to be ended as soon as possible,' he wrote.
Mr Turnbull reminded the Labor leader he was not prime minister.
'He will go out on anything that he thinks gives him a political advantage,' he said.
'He has no concern about our national interest and our national interest is best protected by me giving private counsel to the United States, our most important ally, (and) publicly refraining from commenting on their domestic policy.'
